briefings.headline: TSMC Announces Record Capital Spending of Up to $56 Billion to Ease Capacity Shortage
briefings.dek: The world’s largest chipmaker projected 30% revenue growth for 2026 while working to boost production capacity for advanced AI chips.
briefings.body:
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company on Thursday announced a record capital expenditure between $52 billion and $56 billion for 2026, as it tries to ease the capacity constraint on its production facilities.

About 70% to 80% of the spending will go to manufacturing equipment for cutting-edge chips, with the remainder split between chips for automotive and industrial uses, and advanced packaging technologies, TSMC CFO Wendell Huang said on an earnings call. By comparison, the company’s capital expenditure was $40.9 billion in 2025 and $29.8 billion in 2024.

TSMC, which manufactures more than 90% of the world’s most advanced semiconductors, projects its revenue will grow nearly 30% this year. The company reported revenue in the December quarter grew 25.5% to $33.7 billion from a year earlier, and full-year 2025 revenue climbed 35.9% to $122 billion. The revenue growth is driven by tech companies racing to build AI infrastructure.

CEO C.C. Wei said on the call that demand for cutting-edge AI chips continues to outstrip what TSMC can produce. Since new factories take two to three years to build, the company plans to squeeze more output from existing plants and upgrade older equipment to help bridge the gap over the next two years.

Wei addressed concerns about whether demand for AI chips can last. “You’re trying to ask us whether AI demand is real or not. I’m also very nervous about it,” he told analysts. “If we don’t do it carefully, that’d be a big disaster for TSMC.”

related_items.title: TSMC Can’t Make AI Chips Fast Enough

briefings.headline: Alibaba Announces Major Upgrade of AI App for Consumers
briefings.dek: The Qwen AI app, which went through a makeover in November, is now the centerpiece of Alibaba’s AI strategy for consumers.
briefings.body:
Chinese tech giant Alibaba Group is connecting its Qwen AI app with the company’s e-commerce, online travel and payment platforms, in a major upgrade that enables the chatbot to serve as an agent helping users with real-life tasks like ordering food online and booking trips.

The upgrade allows the Qwen app to tap into Alibaba’s major platforms like the Taobao shopping app and the Fliggy travel app, as well as affiliate Ant Group’s Alipay app. The move shows how the Qwen chatbot app, which went through a complete makeover and was relaunched as a new app in November, is now the centerpiece of Alibaba’s AI strategy for consumers. Alibaba said the app, powered by the company’s own AI foundation models, now has 100 million monthly active users.

Alibaba said the latest upgrade is part of its strategy to bring advanced AI capabilities into “practical, everyday use.” For example, the integration with Taobao’s instant commerce service—which offers a one-hour delivery of groceries and other everyday items—allows the Qwen app to order food and beverages online and complete the purchases for users.

The latest upgrade comes after the Qwen app last month integrated Alibaba’s popular mapping app, Amap. The access to Amap enabled Qwen to offer more accurate and relevant travel planning as well as restaurant and hotel recommendations.

briefings.headline: OpenAI Hires Three AI Researchers From Murati’s Thinking Machines Lab
briefings.dek: It's a coup for OpenAI after the three men departed more than a year ago to help establish a younger rival.
briefings.body:
OpenAI has rehired prominent AI researchers Barret Zoph, Luke Metz, and Sam Schoenholz, who had been working at rival Thinking Machines Lab, according to an X post from OpenAI applications chief Fidji Simo.

The three researchers left OpenAI in late 2024 to help establish Thinking Machines, a high-profile startup led by former OpenAI Chief Technology Officer Mira Murati, who left around the same time. Zoph was CTO at Thinking Machines and will now report to Simo, who oversees ChatGPT. Previously, Zoph led post-training, or techniques the company uses to improve AI performance after their initial development.

When the three researchers left OpenAI more than a year ago, OpenAI was facing adversity because of a string of departures from its vaunted research organization.

Murati on Wednesday said in a post on X that Soumith Chintala, a well-known AI researcher hired in November, will be the new CTO of Thinking Machines.

Thinking Machines is looking to make a name for itself in an increasingly crowded field of so-called neolabs, startups that hope to use new approaches to developing AI models they say major firms such as OpenAI and Anthropic may have overlooked. Thinking Machines, which was last valued at $10 billion, was in talks at the end of last year to raise between $4 billion and $5 billion in new funding at a valuation of at least $50 billion.

briefings.headline: OpenAI Signs $10 Billion Compute Deal With Chipmaker Cerebras
briefings.dek: OpenAI commits to spend 750 megawatts of computing power from Cerebras
briefings.body:
OpenAI on Wednesday announced a computing partnership with AI chip startup Cerebras Systems. As part of the deal, OpenAI plans to purchase 750 megawatts of computing power from the company through 2028, according to an OpenAI blog post.

The deal is worth at least $10 billion, reported The Wall Street Journal.

“OpenAI’s compute strategy is to build a resilient portfolio that matches the right systems to the right workloads,” said OpenAI’s Sachin Katti in the company’s blog post.  Cerebras chips will help with faster responses and “more natural interactions” for its AI.

Cerebras, backed by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, is in talks to raise about $1 billion at a $22 billion pre-money valuation, The Information previously reported. The company is also expected to list in the coming months.

briefings.headline: Oracle Faces Lawsuit Over $18 Billion Bond Offering
briefings.dek: A $4 billion segment of the offering is trading at 95.75 cents on the dollar, according to FINRA data.
briefings.body:
The Ohio Carpenters’ Pension Plan sued Oracle, alleging the tech company didn’t properly disclose it would need to raise additional debt to satisfy its roughly $300 billion cloud computing contract with OpenAI when it sold $18 billion in bonds last year.

Oracle’s bond offering documents did not tell investors the company would need additional debt to build the AI infrastructure and that it was already in the process of seeking more funding, the complaint alleged.

Purchasers of the bonds suffered “significant losses and damages” after media reports about a $38 billion debt offering to fund new data centers for the OpenAI contract sent the price of the Oracle bonds lower, the complaint alleged. The debt offering was for two data centers being developed by Vantage Data Centers, The Information reported.

A $4 billion segment of the Oracle bond offering is trading at 95.75 cents on the dollar, according to FINRA data, implying losses of about $170 million on those securities.

The pension plan’s complaint, filed as a proposed class action lawsuit in a New York state court, named Oracle executive chairman Larry Ellison and former CEO Safra Catz among the defendants, along with banks that underwrote the bond offering. An Oracle spokesperson declined to comment.

briefings.headline: Gemini Can Now Use Information From Users’ Other Google Apps
briefings.dek: The new feature leans into Google’s biggest advantage over rivals like OpenAI: the wide range of data Google has from other areas of users’ lives.
briefings.body:
Google announced on Wednesday that its Gemini chatbot can now access information from users’ other Google apps, if users opt in.

The new feature, dubbed Personal Intelligence, leans into Google’s biggest advantage over rivals like OpenAI: the wide range of data Google has from other areas of users’ lives, which could make for a more effective AI personal assistant. Users can opt in to connect their Gmail, YouTube, Photos and Search information to Gemini. In a blog post, Google’s VP for Gemini, Josh Woodward, said that he had used the new feature to get new tires for his minivan, with Gemini referencing photos from a family vacation to suggest that he might need tires for all-weather conditions.

The Gemini update follows a slew of other recent announcements highlighting the power of Google’s ecosystem and distribution relationships. Earlier this week, Google and Apple announced that Apple would use Google’s Gemini models to power its Siri assistant. Google has also integrated Gemini across its apps like Gmail and Docs, as well as its Chrome browser.

related_items.title: Google Exec Says Data Gives It an Edge in AI Search

briefings.headline: Airbnb Hires Former Meta AI Leader as CTO
briefings.dek: Airbnb hopes Al-Dahle can help the company use AI to overhaul its operations.
briefings.body:
Airbnb hired a onetime Meta Platforms AI leader, Ahmad Al-Dahle, as Chief Technology Officer, as the travel bookings firm grapples with integrating AI features into its operations. Al-Dahle’s role at Meta had been diminished over the past year, after  Meta overhauled the team last year and created a new Superintelligence Labs unit under former Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang and former GitHub CEO Nat Friedman.

Airbnb already uses AI in its customer service and in an interview with The Information’s TITV, Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky outlined other ways AI could transform Airbnb. Hosts, for instance, could use AI to create listings. AI should also make Airbnb employees more productive.

Al-Dahle oversaw Meta’s generative AI team formed in early 2023, shortly after the launch of ChatGPT sparked a rush of companies into the sector. In May of last year Meta cut the team in two and then restructured it further after the hiring of Wang and Friedman. In October Meta cut about 600 people from the AI team.

briefings.headline: China’s Zhipu Launches AI Model Trained Entirely With Huawei Chips
briefings.dek: The move aligns with Beijing’s effort to promote domestic chips and reduce the country’s dependence on Nvidia.
briefings.body:
Chinese AI developer Zhipu on Wednesday released a new open-source AI image model trained entirely with chips from Huawei Technologies. The move is the latest example of how China is ramping up its effort to reduce its dependence on American AI chips and become more self-sufficient in critical areas of technology.

Beijing-based Zhipu described the new model, GLM-Image, as China’s first state-of-the-art AI model that completed the entire process of training on domestic chips. The company said it hopes that the new model will serve as “valuable references” for the industry to tap into the potential of China’s domestic chips.

The company’s Hong Kong-listed shares soared 19% on Wednesday following the announcement. Zhipu, founded by a group of researchers at Tsinghua University, went public on Friday under its corporate name, Knowledge Atlas Technology. The stock has increased more than 36% since the debut.

Zhipu’s launch of the Huawei-trained model aligns with the Chinese government’s policy of promoting domestic alternatives to Nvidia. The Information reported on Tuesday that the Chinese government told some tech companies it would only approve their H200 purchases under special circumstances, such as for university research and development labs.

briefings.headline: Beijing Restricts Nvidia’s H200 Purchase, Banning the Chips From Entering China
briefings.dek: The Chinese government has told companies not to buy Nvidia’s chips unless necessary, banning the chips from entering the country
briefings.body:
The Chinese government this week told companies it would only approve their purchases of Nvidia’s H200 AI chips under special circumstances, such as for university research and development labs, The Information reported on Tuesday.

The directive comes roughly one month after President Donald Trump announced that he would allow Nvidia to sell the H200 chip to China, marking the biggest rollback of Biden-era semiconductor export restrictions. The H200 would be the most advanced AI chip allowed for export to China, despite being one generation behind the Blackwell that’s being used by U.S. companies now.

Separately, Reuters reported on Wednesday that Chinese customs authorities this week told customs brokers that the H200 chips are not permitted to enter the country, citing people briefed on the matter.

Customs authorities did not offer any explanation for their directive, nor provided further guidance on whether the ban would be permanent or just temporary, according to Reuters.

related_items.title: China Restricts Nvidia Chip Purchases to Special Circumstances

briefings.headline: Chinese AI Video Generator Kling Hits $240 Million Annual Run Rate
briefings.dek: Shares of Kling’s owner, Kuaishou, rose on the news of growing revenue.
briefings.body:
Chinese social media firm Kuaishou Technology said its AI video generator, Kling AI, achieved monthly revenue of $20 million in December, boosting its annualized run rate to $240 million from $100 million in March. Kuaishou’s Hong Kong-listed stock closed up 4.5% on Wednesday following the announcement.

Kling’s revenue figure is significant compared to other Chinese AI video generators. For example, Kling’s major competitor Hailuo AI, operated by MiniMax Group, generated $17.5 million in revenue over a nine-month period through September 2025, according to MiniMax’s IPO filings.

MiniMax’s IPO filing also showed that the company is unprofitable. Unlike MiniMax and other upstart rivals that specialize in AI models and apps, Kuaishou earns most of its revenue and profit from its short-video app that competes with ByteDance in China. This means Kuaishou doesn’t need to rely on Kling for profit. Kuaishou’s revenue in the third quarter of 2025 grew 14% to $5.1 billion from the same period a year ago.

briefings.headline: DeepSeek Proposes Technique to Increase Efficiency in New Paper
briefings.dek: The paper was released when the Chinese AI developer is nearing the launch of its next-generation AI model.
briefings.body:
In a new research paper published this week, DeepSeek’s founder and researchers proposed a new technique that makes AI models more efficient by allowing them to retrieve simple factual information without relying on a compute-intensive process.

The technique, called Engram, enables AI models to look up basic, static factual information in a separate memory system, instead of reconstructing that knowledge every time, which requires significantly more computing power. By doing so, the technique can free up computing resources to be used for more complex reasoning tasks.

DeepSeek is close to launching its next-generation flagship AI model, V4, which features strong coding capabilities, The Information reported last week. V4, a successor to the V3 model the firm released in December 2024, is expected to be released around the Lunar New Year in mid-February.

The research paper, entitled “Conditional Memory via Scalable Lookup,” was co-authored by DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng and several DeepSeek researchers, as well as a few researchers from Peking University.  DeepSeek also released the code for Engam on Github.

related_items.title: DeepSeek To Release Next Flagship AI Model With Strong Coding Ability

briefings.headline: U.K. Prime Minister Backs Investigation into Elon Musk’s X Over Grok AI Images
briefings.dek: The probe is prompted by concerns that X is allowing users to create non-consensual sexualized images with the Grok AI tool.
briefings.body:
U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer said it will back an investigation launched earlier this week by its online safety watchdog into Elon Musk’s X over concerns that the social media site’s Grok AI tool allows nonconsensual sexual imagery.

“If X cannot control Grok, we will,” Starmer said, according to BBC.

The watchdog, Ofcom, said earlier this week that there have been “deeply concerning reports” of undressed images of people and sexualized images of children being created and shared on X.

If the probe finds that the company has broken U.K.’s Online Safety Act, the watchdog could impose fines of up to 10% of X’s worldwide revenue. In the most serious case of “ongoing non-compliance,” it could seek a court order to force internet providers to block access to the site in the U.K., Ofcom added.

U.K. Technology Secretary Liz Kendall also told BBC that she welcomed the watchdog’s investigation and urged it to complete it as soon as possible.

briefings.headline: Anthropic Moves Chief Product Officer Krieger to Labs Group
briefings.dek: The company credited the Labs group with Claude Code, its virtual assistant Cowork and other new products.
briefings.body:
Anthropic said Tuesday it was moving Mike Krieger, the Instagram co-founder who has been its chief product officer for the past two years, to a new Labs group that will focus on experimental products based on its Claude models.

Ami Vora, who joined the AI startup in December after holding senior product roles at e-commerce company Faire as well as Meta’s WhatsApp and Facebook, will become head of product. The reorg follows the release earlier this week of Cowork,  a version of its popular Claude Code coding agent designed to handle non-coding tasks on a user’s device. (Corrects Vora’s title.)

“The speed of advancement in AI demands a different approach to how we build, how we organize, and where we focus,“ said Daniela Amodei, President of Anthropic. “Labs gives us room to break the mold and explore.”

briefings.headline: Amazon Backs Away From Tariff Concessions to Vendors
briefings.dek: The impact of Trump’s tariffs were not as bad as feared
briefings.body:
Amazon is cutting what it pays suppliers for products affected by President Trump’s tariffs, the Financial Times reported. Amazon last year agreed to pay more to some suppliers to help them deal with the cost of the tariffs and in an effort to keep the cost of goods on the platform low. But the impact of the tariffs have not been as intense as originally feared, prompting Amazon’s change of heart, the Financial Times report said.

Amazon’s change of mind comes as the Supreme Court is expected to rule on the legality of Trump’s tariffs as soon as this week. An Amazon spokesperson told The Information that their annual vendor negotiation cycles have not changed and that prices of products in their store have not increased outside normal fluctuations. Amazon says the company talked to suppliers about cost reductions based on the reduction of tariff rates to China in November.

briefings.headline: Penske Media Sues Google, Alleging Illegal Manipulation of Ad Market
briefings.dek: In the past two years, Google lost a pair of monopoly suits brought by the Justice Department, and companies have started to sue Google based on the monopoly findings.
briefings.body:
Penske Media, the publisher of Rolling Stone and other entertainment brands, sued Google on Tuesday, alleging that Penske and its subsidiary SheMedia have lost money as a result of what a federal judge ruled last year was Google’s illegal monopoly over the market for advertising technology.

Penske alleged that Google’s monopoly over selling digital advertising resulted in lower advertising prices and excluded rival exchanges, thus depressing Penske’s revenue. In a statement, a Google spokesperson called Penske’s allegations “meritless.” “Advertisers and publishers have many choices and when they choose Google’s ad tech tools it’s because they are effective, affordable and easy to use,” the spokesperson said.

In the past two years, Google lost a pair of monopoly suits brought by the Justice Department, with federal judges ruling that Google had used exclusive distribution deals to illegally maintain its search monopoly, and that Google had a monopoly in the part of its ad tech business that helps independent websites sell ad space. Companies have started to sue Google based on the monopoly findings. Yelp sued Google in 2024, alleging that Google used its monopoly in search to gain an advantage over competitors like Yelp in the local search business.

Penske’s lawsuit follows a suit it filed against Google last September over traffic drops it blamed on AI Overviews, arguing that Google was illegally tying inclusion in its AI Overviews product, which some publishers have complained about, to being indexed in search, a lifeblood for most website publishers. Google on Monday filed to dismiss the September suit, arguing that Penske’s claims weren’t supported by the law.

briefings.headline: Slack Gives Its Digital Assistant an AI Upgrade
briefings.dek: While the Slack digital assistant has long handled basic tasks like helping new users get started on the service, Salesforce has much bigger aspirations for it.
briefings.body:
Salesforce’s Slack unit has officially launched an overhauled version of Slackbot, a digital assistant that has long handled basic tasks like sending alerts to users, in the latest sign of the software provider’s growing focus on using AI to improve products.

The new version of Slackbot lets users ask questions and get answers by tapping into and understanding the context of Slack conversations as well as data from Salesforce’s applications. It is similar in some ways to enterprise search startup Glean, although it doesn’t currently have as many connections to applications and data from other software providers.

The revamped Slackbot launch is one of Salesforce’s biggest upgrades to Slack since it plunked down nearly $28 billion to buy the workplace chat firm more than five years ago. And it sheds more light on what Salesforce co-founder and CTO Parker Harris has been working on since assuming the role of Slack CTO two years ago.

briefings.headline: Meta Considers Doubling Ray-Ban Glasses Production
briefings.dek: The company is scaling back its hardware efforts as it goes big on smart glasses.
briefings.body:
Meta Platforms and EssilorLuxottica have discussed the possibility of doubling production of their AI-powered smart glasses this year, as demand grows and more competitors enter the market. According to Bloomberg, Meta has floated the idea of increasing production capacity to 20 million units, or perhaps more, in 2026.

The discussions show how Meta is putting more resources into its smart glasses, as the company gears its business toward artificial intelligence and scales back its broader hardware efforts. Meta is beginning this week to lay off around 10% of its Reality Labs division, which has around 15,000 employees.

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg spent billions of dollars in recent years on building out his vision for the “metaverse.” However the company’s virtual reality headsets have struggled to gain mainstream traction. More recently, Zuckerberg has pivoted the company’s focus to AI, zeroing in on the smart glasses as a product that can incorporate the technology and potentially reach a bigger audience. Meta’s partnership with European eyewear giant EssilorLuxottica has been central to that effort: in 2024, Meta purchased a small stake in the company.

briefings.headline: Microsoft Pledges to Pay Higher Electricity Rates for Data Centers, Curb Costs for Households
briefings.dek: The announcement comes amid growing political opposition to new data centers.
briefings.body:
Microsoft president Brad Smith on Tuesday promised that the company will pay more for electricity and will subsidize the expansion of the electrical grid in an attempt to head off higher costs for individual households. The company’s promise follows growing concern about new data centers driving up people’s electricity bills.

“We will pay our way as a company to ensure our data centers don’t increase your electricity bill,” Smith said at a Washington, D.C. event Tuesday morning alongside lawmakers and union leaders.

Microsoft also promised to reduce how much water its data centers use by 40% by 2030; to invest in local jobs and skilling programs where it builds data centers; and said it wouldn’t ask local municipalities to grant it tax breaks for new data center projects.

The announcement comes amid growing political opposition to new data centers, with candidates in this year’s midterm elections seizing on fears about rising electricity costs. Local governments in states like Virginia and Pennsylvania have already moved to block the construction of new data centers in recent months. President Donald Trump heralded Microsoft’s pledge in a social media post on Monday night, stating that Microsoft had been working with the White House on its announcement.

briefings.headline: TSMC to Significantly Expand Chipmaking Investments in the U.S.
briefings.dek: The investments are part of trade negotiations between the U.S. and Taiwan
briefings.body:
The Trump administration is close to reaching a trade deal with Taiwan that involves significantly more investments from the island’s largest company, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, according to The New York Times, citing people familiar with the matter.

The potential deal will cut U.S. tariffs on Taiwanese imports to 15% and require TSMC to build at least five more chip fabrication facilities in Arizona, doubling the number of plants the company has previously committed to in the state.

TSMC, which produces 90% of the world’s advanced chips, announced in March that it would invest $100 billion to build three new chip-making plants, in addition to three facilities planned previously. President Donald Trump hailed the deal as the largest foreign direct investment in U.S. history.

briefings.headline: House Passes Bill to Limit China’s Remote Access to U.S. Chips
briefings.dek: The bill could close the loophole in existing export controls where Chinese companies can access advanced chips via overseas data centers.
briefings.body:
The House of Representatives on Monday passed a bipartisan bill that expands U.S. export controls to restrict Chinese companies’ ability to remotely access advanced American AI chips at data centers outside China.

The bill, the Remote Access Security Act, is the latest step in Washington’s effort to limit China’s use of critical U.S. technologies due to national security concerns. It is aimed at regulating Chinese companies that use cloud computing services to rent servers equipped with Nvidia’s AI chips at data centers located in Southeast Asia or other regions outside China.

Such offshore arrangements have become common among Chinese companies as a way to get around U.S. export controls that ban the sale of advanced U.S. chips to China, The Information reported previously. The demand from Chinese companies has helped accelerate the construction of more AI data centers in Southeast Asia. If the bill passes the Senate and becomes law, it could have a big impact on existing cloud server deals involving Chinese companies.

“This bill brings our laws into the digital age and makes it clear that cloud compute is subject to U.S. export control law, just like physical chips. Closing these loopholes will strengthen U.S. national security and protect American innovation,” said John Moolenaar, chairman of the U.S. House Select Committee on China.

related_items.title: Nvidia AI Chip Smuggling to China Becomes an Industry
Google, Microsoft Help Chinese Firms Skirt Ban on Nvidia Chips
